title: J&J: new CEO offers continuity
text:
By most measures, Johnson & Johnson boss Alex Gorsky is going out on a high. He became CEO of the consumer health conglomerate on April 26, 2012. This week J&J announced he will step down in January and become executive chair. Joaquin Duato, a company veteran and Gorsky's longtime protégé, takes up the reins.

Under Gorsky's tenure, J&J underwent massive growth and became a major player in the rare disease space, notably through the $30bn acquisition of Actelion. The company's pharmaceutical business grew from $24bn in sales in 2011 to over $45bn in 2020, thanks in large part to blockbuster cancer treatments Darzalex and Imbruvica. Since Gorsky took over the share price has nearly tripled and its market capitalisation now tops $470bn.

Yet Gorsky also presided over some of the biggest crises in the company's 135-year history. These include claims that the company fuelled the opioid epidemic and allegations of asbestos in its talcum baby powder. The company has incurred $9bn of costs over the past two years from lawsuits related to these claims. Most recently, it agreed to contribute $5bn over nine years to help settle lawsuits related to the opioid crisis. 

The issues, shrugged off by investors, are far from resolved and will continue to dog Duato when he formally takes over.

Overall though, J&J's overall business is in rude health. The company raised its full-year guidance last month as its medical devices unit recovered from the pandemic-related sales slump.

Things are also looking up on the vaccine front. The company said new data showed its single shot vaccine to be highly effective against the fast-spreading Delta variant. That should prove a useful boost after production problems and concerns over reported blood clots weighed on J&J's Covid-19 vaccine.

J&J shares trade on a multiple of 18 times forward earnings, well above Pfizer's 12 times and Bristol-Myers Squibb's 9 times. Duato will have to deliver on the vaccine front to justify this premium.
